Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Fire, Carbon and Climate Change in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Experiences for Students program trains twelve students to conduct research on climate change in Australia, in collaboration with the CSIRO Tropical Ecosystems Research Centre in the Northern Territory of Australia. Undergraduate and graduate students are conducting climate change research under the mentorship of CSIRO scientists.

The investigations conducted by the CSUDH-CSIRO collaboration use the living laboratory of the Northern Territory to test hypotheses on the relationships among fire frequency, fire intensity, climate change, and biodiversity. Investigations are evaluating how management regimes affect rates of carbon sequestration, changes in biodiversity and ecosystem services. Projects may be conducted at multiple sites throughout the Northern Territory, including the Kimberley, Tiwi Islands, western Arnhem land, and in the Darwin region, including the Territory Wildlife Park.
This project provides long-term immersive research experiences in an international setting that are designed to recruited talented students into graduate study emphasizing climate science, and commence the interest and ability to maintain and develop international collaborations. Most students will be members of groups underrepresented in the sciences, reflecting the student population at CSUDH.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program supported research training for twelve students from California State University Dominguez Hills, to conduct research in the CSIRO Tropical Ecosystems Research Centre, located in Darwin, the capital of the Northern Territory in Australia.

These students were conducting mentorship under Australian scientists working on a range of projects in the lab, connected to the main research thrusts of involving interactions between climate change, fire regimes, biodiversity, and invasive species. The students arrived in Darwin in January, in the middle of the rainy season, and were trained in laboratory methods, and then as the dry season commenced in March, they were conducting a combination of field and laboratory research. The returned back to the United States in July, after presenting the findings of their work to the research group in Australia.

The primary purpose of this program was to provide students with training in research and experience with international collaboration, to enhance their professional trajectory towards careers in STEM. Some of the participants are still enrolled as students at CSU Dominguez Hills, and those who have graduated have moved on towards graduate study in STEM or work in industry. Several of the participants are first-generation college students, and eleven are members of groups underrepresented in the sciences.

The research conducted by the participants resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications in well-regarded scientific journals, including information about the spread of non-native species, the natural history of ants of the top end of Australia, and the response of biodiversity to the rehabilitation of minesites. This research also resulted in a closer collaboration between US-based and Australia-based labs.
